Literature Review: Age-related perioperative neurocognitive disorders (PNDs) represent a significant challenge in modern healthcare, particularly as the global population ages. These disorders encompass a range of cognitive impairments that can occur following surgery, including postoperative delirium, cognitive decline, and dementia. Understanding the underlying mechanisms and developing effective interventions are crucial for improving patient outcomes and quality of life. Postoperative delirium (POD) is a common and serious complication in elderly surgical patients, characterized by acute confusion, inattention, and disorganized thinking. The incidence of POD increases with age, and it is associated with longer hospital stays, higher mortality rates, and increased risk of long-term cognitive decline. The exact pathophysiology of POD remains unclear, but several factors, including neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and neurotransmitter imbalances, have been implicated. Neuroinflammation, in particular, has emerged as a key player in the development of PNDs. Animal models have shown that surgery can trigger a systemic inflammatory response, leading to the activation of microglia and astrocytes in the brain. This activation results in the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin-1β (IL-1β), tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), and interleukin-6 (IL-6), which can disrupt synaptic function and contribute to cognitive deficits. Furthermore, chronic low-grade inflammation may exacerbate the cognitive decline observed in elderly patients. To better understand and manage PNDs, accurate and rapid cognitive assessment tools are essential. Traditional neuropsychological tests are often time-consuming and require specialized training, making them impractical for routine use in the perioperative setting. Recent advances in technology have led to the development of tablet-based cognitive assessments that can quickly and reliably measure key domains of executive function, such as memory and attention. These tools offer a promising solution for monitoring cognitive changes in surgical patients and identifying those at risk of PNDs. Several druggable targets have been identified for the prevention and treatment of PNDs. Anti-inflammatory agents, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and corticosteroids, have shown promise in reducing postoperative neuroinflammation and improving cognitive outcomes in animal models. However, the use of these agents in clinical practice is limited by potential side effects, such as gastrointestinal bleeding and immunosuppression. Novel therapeutic approaches, including the use of N-acetylcysteine (NAC) and minocycline, have also been explored. NAC, an antioxidant and glutathione precursor, has been shown to reduce oxidative stress and improve cognitive function in both animal models and clinical trials. Minocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties, has been found to attenuate microglial activation and protect against cognitive decline. In addition to pharmacological interventions, non-pharmacological strategies, such as cognitive training and physical exercise, have been proposed to mitigate the risk of PNDs. Cognitive training programs, which involve structured activities designed to enhance specific cognitive functions, have been shown to improve cognitive performance and reduce the risk of cognitive decline in elderly individuals. Physical exercise, particularly aerobic exercise, has been linked to improved cognitive function and reduced inflammation in both animal models and human studies. Despite these advancements, significant challenges remain in the management of PNDs. The heterogeneity of PNDs, the lack of standardized diagnostic criteria, and the complex interplay between multiple risk factors make it difficult to develop a one-size-fits-all approach. Future research should focus on identifying biomarkers that can predict the risk of PNDs and on developing personalized care pathways that integrate cognitive assessment, pharmacological interventions, and non-pharmacological strategies. In conclusion, age-related perioperative neurocognitive disorders pose a significant threat to the cognitive health of elderly surgical patients. Understanding the pathogenic mechanisms, particularly the role of neuroinflammation, and developing effective assessment tools and therapeutic interventions are critical steps towards improving patient outcomes. By combining pharmacological and non-pharmacological approaches, we can better manage PNDs and enhance the perioperative brain health of our aging population.
